definitions.definition: one more time; on another occasion

examples.text: This must never **happen again**.
**Try again**—it takes practice.
Can we **start again**, please?
Could you say it again, please?
When will I see you again?
This author again proves to be a superb storyteller.
I've told you **again and again** *(= many times)* not to do that.
I'll have to write it **all over again** *(= again from the beginning)*.
She tried **over and over again** *(= many times)* to get it right.
He has **yet again** *(= as has happened many times before)* shown that he cannot be trusted.
**Once again** *(= as had happened several times before)*, the train was late.

definitions.definition: showing that somebody/something is in the same place or state that they were in originally

examples.text: We're very happy to be here together again.
He was glad to be home again.
You'll soon feel well again.
She spends two hours a day getting to work and **back again**.

definitions.definition: added to an amount that is already there

examples.text: The cost is about **half as much again** as it was two years ago.
I'd like **the same again** *(= the same amount or the same thing)*.

definitions.definition: used to show that a comment or fact is connected with what you have just said

examples.text: And again, we must think of the cost.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a fact or an opinion that contrasts with what you have just said

examples.text: We might buy it but then again we might not.

definitions.definition: used when you ask somebody to tell you something or repeat something that you think they have told you already

examples.text: What was the name again?
Every now and again she checked to see if he was still asleep.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to serve you the same drink as before

examples.text: Same again, please!

definitions.definition: often; on many or all occasions

examples.text: You will get a perfect result time after time if you follow these instructions.
Time and again, the girls have shown how strong and determined they can be.

wordOrigin: Old English ongēan, ongægn, etc., of Germanic origin; related to German entgegen ‘opposite’.
